thread.title: Qantas returns to full year profit, and announces order for 8 new planes
thread.title_full: Qantas returns to full year profit, and announces order for 8 new planes

title: Qantas returns to full year profit, and announces order for 8 new planes
text:
Save 
Qantas has returned to full-year profit, labelling them its strongest profits since before the global financial downturn of 2008. 
The airline reported an underlying pre-tax profit of AU$975 million (£457 million) compared with a loss of AU$646 million a year ago. It said it would return cash to shareholders. 
The Australian carrier has also placed an order for eight Boeing Dreamliners. 
Qantas’ return to profitability has been aided by low fuel prices as well as tough cost-cutting measures. The airline has also been aggressively reducing jobs, cutting capacity and altering its frequent flyer programme, the BBC said. 
Chief executive Alan Joyce said the acquisition of eight next-generation Boeing Dreamliners marked the scale of Qantas’ turnaround and signalled a new phase of renewal and growth. 
“We are delivering one of the biggest turnarounds in Australia’s corporate history,” he said. 
“This is the best first half [financial] result in four years and the best second half result in the company’s history.” 
Qantas had previously postponed plans to refresh its fleet of 11 Boeing 747s on long-haul flights, and it now has another 12 options for the Dreamliner from 2017, alongwith a further 30 purchase rights.
